'''''Ramaria flavosaponaria''''' is a species of [[coral fungus]] in the [[Gomphaceae]] family.  It is found in the mountains of eastern [[North America]] from [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and [[Tennessee]] to [[Nova Scotia]].<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>

==Names==
The [[Specific name (zoology)|specific epithet]] is from the {{lang|la|flavo}} ('yellow')<ref name=ChuckG>{{cite web |url=http://www.winternet.com/~chuckg/dictionary/dictionary.88.html |title=Dictionary of Botanical Epithets |last=Griffith |first=Chuck |year=2005 |website=Dictionary of Botanical Epithets |language=English |access-date=16 July 2018 |quote=flavus flav adj golden yellow, reddish yellow, flaxen, blonde o o cnct connective vowel in botanical Latin, usually for Greek words but in some cases, such as color tingeing, for Latin words }}</ref> and {{lang|la|saponaria}} ('soapy'),<ref name=ChuckG2>{{cite web |url=http://www.winternet.com/~chuckg/dictionary/dictionary.161.html |title=Dictionary of Botanical Epithets |last=Griffith |first=Chuck |year=2005 |website=Dictionary of Botanical Epithets |language=English |access-date=16 July 2018 |quote=saponarius saponaria saponarium soapy sapo sapon noun/m soap (from German) arius ari adj adjective suffix for nouns or numbers: connected to or possessed by }}</ref> both of which are distinguishing features of the mushroom.<ref name="Petersen"/>  The name was originally published as ''Ramaria flavo-saponaria'', including a hyphen.<ref name="Petersen"/>  However, this is considered erroneous by the [[International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants]], so the proper [[orthography]] is ''Ramaria flavosaponaria''.<ref name="ICN">{{cite book |editor1-last=Turland |editor1-first=N. J. |editor2-last=Wiersema |editor2-first=J. H. |editor3-last=Barrie |editor3-first=F. R. |editor4-last=Greuter |editor4-first=W. |editor5-last=Hawksworth |editor5-first=D. L. |editor6-last=Herendeen |editor6-first=P. S. |editor7-last=Knapp |editor7-first=S. |editor8-last=Kusber |editor8-first=W.-H. |editor9-last=Li |editor9-first=D.-Z. |editor10-last=Marhold |editor10-first=K. |editor11-last=May |editor11-first=T. W. |editor12-last=McNeill |editor12-first=J. |editor13-last=Monro |editor13-first=A. M. |editor14-last=Prado |editor14-first=J. |editor15-last=Price |editor15-first=M. J. |editor16-last=Smith |editor16-first=G. F. |title=International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (Shenzhen Code) adopted by the Nineteenth International Botanical Congress Shenzhen, China, July 2017 |date=2018 |publisher=Glashütten: Koeltz Botanical Books |isbn=9783946583165 |oclc=1043224136 |series=Regnum Vegetabile |volume=159 |chapter-url=https://www.iapt-taxon.org/nomen/pages/main/art_60.html#Art60.11 |accessdate=19 July 2018 |doi=10.12705/Code.2018 |language=English |chapter=Chapter viii Orthography and gender of names Section 1 orthography Article 60 |quote=The use of a hyphen in a compound epithet is treated as an error to be corrected by deletion of the hyphen. A hyphen is permitted only when the epithet is formed of words that usually stand independently, or when the letters before and after the hyphen are the same}}</ref>

Before being [[Species description|formally described]] in 1986 by [[Ron Petersen]], the species was labelled in [[scientific collection]]s under various names.<ref name="Petersen"/>  ''Ramaria aurea'' sensu mihi was used for its resemblance to the European ''[[Ramaria aurea]]''.<ref name="Petersen"/>  It was also sometimes labeled ''Ramaria aquafaba'',<ref name="Petersen"/> at least as early as 1969,<ref name="CPNWH">{{cite web |title=Ramaria aquafaba |url=http://www.pnwherbaria.org/data/results.php?DisplayAs=WebPage&ExcludeCultivated=Y&GroupBy=ungrouped&SortBy=Year&SortOrder=DESC&SearchAllHerbaria=Y&QueryCount=1&IncludeSynonyms1=Y&Species1=Aquafaba&Zoom=4&Lat=55&Lng=-135&PolygonCount=0 |website=Consortium of Pacific Northwest herbaria |publisher=WTU Herbarium, Burke Museum, University of Washington |accessdate=19 July 2018 |language=English}}</ref> predating the 2015 coinage of the term [[aquafaba]] in an unrelated culinary usage.<ref name="Ox">{{cite web |author1=<!-- not stated --> |title=aquafaba : Definition of aquafaba in English by Oxford Dictionaries |url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/aquafaba |website=Oxford Living Dictionaries |publisher=Oxford University Press |accessdate=19 July 2018 |language=English |quote=Coined in 2015 from Latin aqua ‘water’ + faba ‘bean’.}}</ref>  This term possibly relates to the use of some yellow species of ''Ramaria'' (possibly including ''R. flavosaponaria'') to make flavorful [[broth]].<ref name="Arora">{{cite web |last1=Arora |first1=David |last2=Bergo |first2=Alan |authorlink1=David Arora |title=Thoughts on Ramarias / Coral Mushrooms |url=http://foragerchef.com/thoughts-on-ramarias-coral-mushrooms/ |website=Forager Chef |accessdate=20 July 2018 |language=English |date=January 2016 |quote=As they give off water in the skillet, taste their broth – in some of the yellow species it is quite delicious!}}</ref>  cooked ''R. flavosaponaria'' has a beany flavor,<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/> so this 'bean water' ([[Latin]] {{Lang|la|aqua}} + {{Lang|la|faba}}<ref name="Ox"/>) likely led to the early ''R. aquafaba'' name.

==Description==
''R. flavosaponaria'' is easily distinguished from related mushrooms by the brilliant gold color, the large number of aborted branchlets, a surface that feels slippery, a lack of [[clamp connection]]s, and a complex [[spore]] ornamentation.<ref name="Petersen"/>  It is sometimes confused with ''[[Ramaria aurea]]'', which only grows in [[Europe]].<ref name="Petersen"/>  ''[[Ramaria stuntzii]]'' also lacks clamps, has small spores, and aborted branchlets, but is a bright red color and not slippery to the touch.<ref name="Petersen"/>   There is also a similar ''[[Ramaria]]'' species in Nova Scotia that is bronze-colored and also not slippery.<ref name="Petersen"/>  [[Macroscopic]]ally ''[[Ramaria primulina]]'' closely resembles ''R. flavosaponaria'', but the former produces larger spores, has clamps, and flesh that is more gelatinous than soapy.<ref name="PetersenNS">{{cite journal |last1=Petersen |first1=Ronald H. |authorlink1=Ron Petersen |title=Some ''Ramaria'' taxa from Nova Scotia |journal=Canadian Journal of Botany |date=August 1986 |volume=64 |issue=8 |pages=1786–1811 |doi=10.1139/b86-238 |language=English |issn=0008-4026 |oclc=4636218425}}</ref>

''R. flavosaponaria'' has fruiting bodies up to {{convert|8|×|12|cm}} in size<ref name="PetersenNS"/> that are broadly [[obovate]] to circular in shape and [[cespitose]] or scattered.<ref name="Petersen"/>  The irregularly shaped [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] grows up to {{convert|3|×|1.5|cm}} with much aborted branching, giving an appearance like [[cauliflower]].<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  The flesh is white to yellow, does not [[bruise]], but has a soapy texture without being gelatinous.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  The above-ground parts are weakly [[vinescent]] (turning to a [[red wine]] color<ref name=vinescent>{{cite web |author1=<!-- not stated --> |title=vinescent |url=http://www.mycobank.org/BioloMICS.aspx?TableKey=14682616000000161&Rec=11393&Fields=All |website=MycoBank |accessdate=17 July 2018 |location=Utrecht, The Netherlands |language=English |editor-first=K. |editor-last=Bensch}}</ref>) around particles of soil.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  The flesh is brittle whether dried or fresh.<ref name="Petersen"/>

The odor of fresh specimens is [[fabaceous]] (bean-like), which becomes like [[fenugreek]] upon drying.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/> The taste is described as moderately fabaceous,<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/> but it is not known if the species is edible.  A [[Colorado]] couple suffered gastrointestinal distress and cramps from a mushroom similar to the European ''R. aurea'', but if this was ''R. flavosaponaria'' or another species is uncertain.<ref name="Beug">{{cite journal |last1=Beug |first1=Michael W. |last2=Shaw |first2=Marilyn |last3=Cochran |first3=Kenneth W. |title=Thirty-Plus Years of Mushroom Poisoning: Summary of the Approximately 2,000 Reports in the NAMA Case Registry |journal=McIlvainea |date=Fall 2006 |volume=16 |issue=2 |page=64 |url=http://www.namyco.org/docs/Poisonings30year.pdf |accessdate=20 July 2018 |language=English |issn=0099-8400 |oclc=703596018 |quote=Ramaria cf. aurea  CO  2 adult, 8 hr    Gastrointestinal distress(2), cramp}}</ref>

The species [[Chemical test in mushroom identification|tests]] positive with [[pyrogallol]].<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  It is moderately positive in response to [[ferric chloride]].<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  Tincture of [[guaiac]] is negative on the branch sections but weakly positive on the surface of the stipe.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  [[Ammonium hydroxide]] and [[potassium hydroxide]] cause bleaching.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  Testing with [[melzer's reagent]] is negative.<ref name="PetersenNS"/>

The [[Trama (mycology)|trama]] [[hypha]]e of the upper branches are no bigger than 7 μm in diameter and appear glassy, are [[hyaline]], and lack clamp connections.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  The areas near the [[Septum|septa]] are inflated up to 15 μm and are ornamented delicately.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  [[Gloeoplerous]] hyphae are not present.<ref name="PetersenNS"/><ref name="Petersen"/> The [[hymenium]] is thickening, with [[clavate]] [[Basidium|basidia]] that also lack clamp connections.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>

The [[wikt:subcylindrical|subcylindrical]] or narrowly [[Glossary of leaf morphology#ovate|ovate]] spores are 3.6-5.4 × 7.2-11.2 μm with roughened profiles.<ref name="Petersen"/>  The spores have walls up to 0.3 μm thick, with ornamentation of low warts and meandering, [[wikt:reticulate|reticulate]], and complex [[cyanophilous]] ridges.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="PetersenNS"/>  [[Spore print]]s are cinnamon buff.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="Ridgway">{{cite book |last1=Ridgway |first1=Robert |authorlink1=Robert Ridgway |title=Color standards and color nomenclature: With fifty-three colored plates and eleven hundred and fifteen named colors |date=1912 |publisher=Robert Ridgway |location=Washington, DC |isbn=9781421261881 |page=Plate XXIX |url=http://lhldigital.lindahall.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/color/id/23684/show/23655 |accessdate=19 July 2018 |language=English |oclc=191675138}}</ref>

==Ecology==
''R. flavosaponaria''  forms [[ectomycorrhiza]]l relationships with ''[[Fagus sylvatica]]'' (European beech).<ref name="Agerer">{{cite book |editor1-last=Agerer |editor1-first=Reinhard |title=Colour Atlas of Ectomycorrhizae |date=1987–2012 |publisher=Einhorn-Verlag |location=Schwäbisch Gmünd |isbn=9783921703779 |chapter-url=http://www.sysbot.biologie.uni-muenchen.de/en/people/agerer/book_ectomyc_atlas.html |accessdate=19 July 2018 |language=English |oclc=263940450 |chapter=Tables of identified ectomycorrhizae |quote=''Ramaria flavo-saponaria'' + ''Fagus selvatica'' (Raidl, Scattolin)}}</ref>  It has been found growing under ''[[Tsuga canadensis]]'' (eastern hemlock) and ''Quercus'' ([[oak]]) trees.<ref name="Petersen"/><ref name="Nirschl">{{cite web |last1=Nirschl |first1=Rick |title=Mushrooms of the Oak Openings |url=http://www.toledonaturalist.org/~naturalist/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/fungifinal3_sheet1.pdf |website=Toledo Naturalists' Association |publisher=Toledo Naturalists' Association |accessdate=19 July 2018 |page=4 |language=English }}</ref>
